author: John Cross
title: Swansea chief Paul Clement says Welsh side's crunch month will decide their destiny
text:
Sport Swansea chief Paul Clement says Welsh side's crunch month will decide their destiny The Swans face their relegation rivals in their next four games and Clement says his side must show they can deal with the pressure Share The Swans have impressed since Clement's arrival (Photo: 2017 Getty Images) Share Get football     
Paul Clement believes Swansea can secure their Premier League safety ahead of a make-or-break month. 
Swansea face Burnley, Hull, Bournemouth and Middlesbrough in their next four games which will go a long way to deciding their fate. 
Clement believes there is more pressure on Swansea to win those games - starting against Burnley at home next Saturday - than getting anything from Chelsea. 
Swansea boss Clement said: “I think it’s a little like the Leicester game, we were level on points with them, everyone was saying it’s a big game, we knew it was a big game, we put in a big performance and won. 
"We have to do the same in the next game against Burnley. Clement was happy with what his side showed at Stamford Bridge (Photo: AFP/Getty Images) 
“There’s arguably more pressure. The players know that but they’ve coped with it very well recently. I think we’ve continued to improve our performances, our shape, we don’t leave here with damaged confidence. 
“Based on chances created they deserved to win. But we had a big moment at 1-1. Who knows what would have happened had that penalty been awarded. It didn’t go our way at Chelsea. We move on.” Llorente scored again against Chelsea - having been persuaded to stay (Photo: REUTERS) 
Clement also revealed that a heart-to-heart with Fernando Llorente when he first took charge persuaded the Spanish striker to stay at Swansea. 
Llorente has been instrumental in their climb to safety and Swansea had to fend off interest from Chelsea to keep him in January. 
Clement added: “I just told him I want him to stay here. It was a very short conversation. There’s a lot of things involved when a player potentially moves. 
“Bottom line is he’s here as a Swansea player, fully committed, you’ve seen that again and he’ll be very important for us moving forward.”
